title: OpenType Pro Didone Recomendation?
content:
Hi everyone,

I’m looking for a Didone that is available as an OpenType family that includes CE characters. What’s out there that fits the bill?

Thanks!

comments.content: Kepler? It isn’t as rationalised as most Didones, but is definitely in that classification.

I think Kepler is a great font, but not a Didone.  
It’s Transitional (as lousy a term as that is.)

hhp

Recently, URW++ has been offering all of their fonts in OpenType PS format in various levels. “Level 1” OpenType fonts from URW++ contain Western & Central European characters, “Level 2” OpenType fonts from URW++ also contain Cyrillic and Greek.

Bodoni Antiqua and Corporate A fonts are offered with the WGL4 character set (West, CE, Cyrillic, Greek):  
 [http://www.urw.de/cgi-bin1/dalcgi/english/wgl4liste0.htd](http://web.archive.org/web/20071126054756/http:/www.urw.de/cgi-bin1/dalcgi/english/wgl4liste0.htd "http://www.urw.de/cgi-bin1/dalcgi/english/wgl4liste0.htd")

More URW++ Didone fonts with just Western and CE can be found at:  
 [http://www.urw.de/cgi-bin1/dalcgi/english/Kliste0.htd?kgruppe1=1&kgruppe...](http://web.archive.org/web/20071126054756/http:/www.urw.de/cgi-bin1/dalcgi/english/Kliste0.htd?kgruppe1=1&kgruppe2=1&kgruppe3=3 "http://www.urw.de/cgi-bin1/dalcgi/english/Kliste0.htd?kgruppe1=1&kgruppe2=1&kgruppe3=3")

ParaType also offers a version of PT Bodoni that includes Western, CE and Cyrillic characters:  
 [http://www.paratype.com/pstore/default.asp?search=Bodoni&fcode=PT\_BDN](http://web.archive.org/web/20071126054756/http:/www.paratype.com/pstore/default.asp?search=Bodoni&fcode=PT_BDN "http://www.paratype.com/pstore/default.asp?search=Bodoni&fcode=PT\_BDN")

Note that ParaType’s Cyrillic version are design-wise usually much better than URW++’s.

Adam

[_Kepler is_] _Transitional (as lousy a term as that is.)_

Well you know what terminology I prefer: Didone = Romantic (e.g. Didot, Bodoni), Transitional = Neo-Classical (e.g. Baskerville, Bulmer).

Kepler is interesting because it really is transitional, occupying a space somewhere between neo-classical and romantic, but a bit too informal to comfortably occupy either.
